tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: This question requires calculating the ratio of natural frequencies, involving concepts from vibrations and structural mechanics. It requires understanding the modes of vibration and applying appropriate formulas, making it a multi-step numerical calculation with moderate difficulty.

answer_validation.reasoning: Model the uniform rigid bar (mass m, length l) suspended by two identical vertical springs of stiffness k attached at the ends. Choose generalized coordinates: vertical translation of the center y and small rotation \(\theta\) about the center (positive counterclockwise). For small motion, vertical displacement of left and right ends are \(y - (l/2)\theta\) and \(y + (l/2)\theta\). Spring forces (upward) are \(k(y - l\theta/2)\) and \(k(y + l\theta/2)\). Total potential energy: \(V = \tfrac{1}{2}k(y - l\theta/2)^2 + \tfrac{1}{2}k(y + l\theta/2)^2 = k y^2 + k l^2 \theta^2/4\). Kinetic energy: \(T = \tfrac{1}{2} m \dot y^2 + \tfrac{1}{2} I_c \dot \theta^2\) with \(I_c = m l^2/12\) for a slender bar about its center. Thus mass matrix is diagonal: \(M = \text{diag}(m, m l^2/12)\), stiffness matrix \(K = \text{diag}(2k, k l^2/2)\). The eigenvalue problem \(|K - \omega^2 M| = 0\) gives two uncoupled frequencies: \(\omega_1^2 = 2k/m\) (pure vertical translation, mode I) and \(\omega_2^2 = (k l^2/2)/(m l^2/12) = 6k/m\) (pure rotation, mode II). Therefore \(\omega_2/\omega_1 = \sqrt{6k/m} / \sqrt{2k/m} = \sqrt{3} \approx 1.732\). Rounded to one decimal place, this is 1.7, which lies in the official answer range 1.7 to 1.8.

step_by_step: Identify degrees of freedom: the rigid bar can move vertically as a whole and rotate about its center. Choose generalized coordinates y (vertical displacement of center) and \(\theta\) (small rotation).
Express vertical displacements of the left and right ends in terms of y and \(\theta\): left end \(y_L = y - (l/2)\theta\), right end \(y_R = y + (l/2)\theta\).

Write spring forces and potential energy. Each spring stores \(\tfrac{1}{2}k y_i^2\). Summing both gives total potential energy \(V = \tfrac{1}{2}k(y - l\theta/2)^2 + \tfrac{1}{2}k(y + l\theta/2)^2\). Simplify to obtain \(V = k y^2 + (k l^2/4)\theta^2\).

Write kinetic energy of the rigid bar: \(T = \tfrac{1}{2} m \dot y^2 + \tfrac{1}{2} I_c \dot \theta^2\), where \(I_c = m l^2/12\) is the mass moment of inertia of a uniform slender bar about its center.

From T and V, read off the mass and stiffness matrices: \(M = \text{diag}(m, m l^2/12)\) and \(K = \text{diag}(2k, k l^2/2)\) (factor 2 in translational stiffness because two springs act in parallel).

Set up the eigenvalue problem for free vibration: \(|K - \omega^2 M| = 0|. Since M and K are diagonal, the two modes are uncoupled: \(\omega_1^2 = 2k/m\) and \(\omega_2^2 = (k l^2/2)/(m l^2/12) = 6k/m\).
Compute the ratio of natural frequencies: \(\omega_2/\omega_1 = \sqrt{6k/m} / \sqrt{2k/m} = \sqrt{3} \approx 1.732\). Round to one decimal place to obtain 1.7.

topic.name: Vibration of discrete systems (multi-degree-of-freedom, rigid body modes)
topic.syllabus_ref: Section 3 Structures -> Structural dynamics and aeroelasticity -> Free and forced vibration of discrete systems

concepts.name: Rigid body vibration modes (translation and rotation)
Mass and stiffness matrices for multi-degree-of-freedom systems
Kinetic and potential energy of a rigid bar
Mode shapes: symmetric and antisymmetric motion

essential: Understanding of free vibration and natural frequency for spring-mass systems
Rigid body kinematics: translation and small rotation of a bar
Expression for mass moment of inertia of a uniform slender bar
Formulation of kinetic and potential energy for mechanical systems
Eigenvalue problem for multi-degree-of-freedom vibration (determinant of K - omega^2 M)
helpful: Lagrange\'s equations for deriving equations of motion
Physical interpretation of symmetric and antisymmetric vibration modes

Main Concept: requires: Free vibration theory and natural frequency definition
requires: Rigid body kinematics and mass moment of inertia
enables: Construction of mass and stiffness matrices for MDOF systems
enables: Modal analysis and understanding of rigid body and elastic modes in complex structures

difficulty_factors: Requires identifying correct degrees of freedom (translation and rotation) for a rigid bar
Needs careful derivation of kinetic and potential energies and recognition that modes are uncoupled
Students may be tempted to treat the bar as a point mass and miss the rotational mode

textbook_references.author: S. S. Rao
textbook_references.section: Rigid body modes and semi-definite systems
textbook_references.text_snippet: Examples of rigid bars supported by springs are used to illustrate translational and rotational modes, construction of mass and stiffness matrices, and computation of natural frequencies.

textbook_references.author: W. T. Thomson and M. D. Dahleh
textbook_references.section: Rigid body modes of bars and plates
textbook_references.text_snippet: Derives natural frequencies of a rigid bar suspended by springs, showing separate translational and rotational modes.

video_references.professor: Prof. S. K. Dwivedy / Prof. Rajiv Tiwari
video_references.topic_covered: Semi-definite systems and rigid body modes in two-degree-of-freedom systems
Modal analysis and rigid body modes in continuous and discrete systems

step_by_step_solution.solution_path: Choose DOFs (translation and rotation) \u2192 Express end displacements \u2192 Derive T and V \u2192 Form M and K matrices \u2192 Solve eigenvalue problem \u2192 Obtain two natural frequencies \u2192 Take ratio and round
key_insights: Because the springs are identical and attached at the ends, the translational and rotational motions decouple, giving diagonal M and K matrices.
Mode I is pure vertical translation (both springs extend equally), while Mode II is pure rotation (one spring extends, the other compresses).
The frequency ratio depends only on geometry and inertia distribution, not on m, k, or l individually, leading to the simple result \(\sqrt{3}\).

formulas_principles.name: Kinetic energy of a rigid bar with translation and rotation
formulas_principles.conditions: Applies to a uniform rigid bar undergoing small vertical translation and small rotation about its center
formulas_principles.relevance: Used to construct the mass matrix for the 2-DOF system

formulas_principles.name: Potential energy stored in two end springs
formulas_principles.conditions: Two identical linear springs attached vertically at the ends of the bar
formulas_principles.relevance: Leads to the stiffness matrix and shows decoupling of translation and rotation

formulas_principles.name: Mass moment of inertia of a uniform slender bar about its center
formulas_principles.conditions: Bar of length l and mass m, axis through centroid and perpendicular to length
formulas_principles.relevance: Needed to compute rotational kinetic energy and rotational natural frequency

formulas_principles.name: Eigenvalue equation for natural frequencies
formulas_principles.conditions: Linear undamped free vibration of a multi-degree-of-freedom system
formulas_principles.relevance: Core principle to obtain natural frequencies from mass and stiffness matrices

industry_examples: Vibration analysis of suspended equipment racks or avionics trays mounted by multiple springs in aircraft fuselages
Design of payload suspension systems in satellites where rigid instruments are supported by isolators to reduce launch vibration loads
specific_systems: Instrument panels in aircraft cockpits mounted on vibration isolators
Optical benches in spacecraft supported by flexures or springs
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Knowing translational and rotational natural frequencies helps engineers avoid resonance with engine or aerodynamic excitation, improving structural integrity and passenger comfort.

common_mistakes.mistake: Treating the bar as a point mass attached to two parallel springs and ignoring rotational motion, leading to only one natural frequency.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They focus on the obvious vertical motion and forget that a rigid body generally has both translation and rotation degrees of freedom.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Always ask: Can this body also rotate? For any extended rigid body, explicitly check for rotational DOFs and include the mass moment of inertia.
common_mistakes.consequence: You miss the second mode and cannot compute the required frequency ratio.

common_mistakes.mistake: Incorrect expression for end displacements, e.g., using y ± l\theta instead of y ± (l/2)\theta.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Confusion about measuring rotation about the center versus about an end.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Sketch the bar, mark the center and ends, and write displacement as center displacement plus/minus distance from center times rotation.
common_mistakes.consequence: Leads to wrong stiffness terms and an incorrect frequency ratio.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using wrong moment of inertia, such as \(I = m l^2/3\) (about an end) instead of \(m l^2/12\) (about the center).
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Memorizing formulas without associating them with the correct axis location.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Remember that for a uniform bar: center axis uses 1/12, end axis uses 1/3. Here rotation is about the center, so use 1/12.
common_mistakes.consequence: Rotational natural frequency is significantly off, giving an incorrect ratio.

common_mistakes.mistake: Forgetting that two identical springs in parallel double the translational stiffness, using k instead of 2k.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They focus on one spring and overlook that both act together in translation.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: For pure translation, imagine the bar moving without rotation: both springs extend equally, so total force is 2k times displacement.
common_mistakes.consequence: Translational frequency is underestimated by factor \(\sqrt{2}\), altering the ratio.

mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: Rigid bar = 2 DOF: Up and Twist
mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Always include both translation and rotation for a rigid bar supported by springs
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: When setting up vibration models for bars or plates supported by discrete springs

mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Moment of inertia of a uniform bar about its center is \(I = m l^2/12\)
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Choosing correct inertia in kinetic energy expressions

flashcards.front: For a uniform rigid bar suspended by two identical end springs, what are the two natural modes of vibration?
flashcards.back: Mode I: Pure vertical translation of the bar (both springs extend/compress equally). Mode II: Pure rotation about the center (one spring extends while the other compresses).

flashcards.front: What is the mass moment of inertia of a uniform slender bar of mass m and length l about its center?
flashcards.back: For a uniform slender bar about its centroidal axis perpendicular to its length: \(I_c = m l^2/12\).

flashcards.front: A rigid bar of mass m and length l is suspended by two identical springs k at its ends. Write expressions for the vertical displacements of the left and right ends in terms of center displacement y and small rotation \(\theta\).
flashcards.back: Left end: \(y_L = y - (l/2)\theta\). Right end: \(y_R = y + (l/2)\theta\).

flashcards.front: For the bar-spring system, the translational natural frequency squared is what in terms of k and m?
flashcards.back: Since two springs act in parallel for pure translation, effective stiffness is 2k, so \(\omega_1^2 = 2k/m\).

flashcards.front: Given \(\omega_1^2 = 2k/m\) and \(\omega_2^2 = 6k/m\) for a rigid bar on two springs, what is \(\omega_2/\omega_1\)?

real_world_context.application: Vibration isolation of avionics boxes or instrument racks mounted on multiple springs or isolators
real_world_context.industry_example: In aircraft, heavy electronic racks are mounted on four or more isolators. Engineers compute both translational and rotational natural frequencies to avoid resonance with engine or aerodynamic excitation frequencies.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: If the rotational mode coincides with excitation, instruments can experience large angular motions, leading to connector failures or loss of function.

real_world_context.application: Suspended payloads in satellites and launch vehicles
real_world_context.industry_example: Optical payloads are often mounted on flexures or springs to isolate them from launch vibrations. Designers analyze rigid body modes similar to this bar-spring system to ensure that natural frequencies are outside the strong excitation bands of the launch vehicle.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Incorrect prediction of rigid body modes can cause optical misalignment or structural damage during launch.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Recognize it as a standard rigid bar on springs problem. Quickly set DOFs (y, \theta), recall \(I_c = m l^2/12\), and note that translation and rotation decouple, giving simple formulas for \(\omega_1^2\) and \(\omega_2^2\).
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If stuck, remember that rotational modes are usually higher frequency than translational ones and that ratios like \(\sqrt{2}\) or \(\sqrt{3}\) are common; here a value around 1.7 (between 1.4 and 2.0) is reasonable.
exam_strategy.time_management: Aim to finish within 2–3 minutes: 1 minute to set up DOFs and energies, 1 minute to compute frequencies and ratio, leaving time to double-check inertia and end displacements.

search_keywords: rigid bar suspended by springs natural frequencies
two degree of freedom rigid body vibration translation rotation
mass and stiffness matrix for bar on springs
GATE AE vibrations rigid bar problem
moment of inertia uniform bar ml2/12

alternative_methods.name: Direct Newton-Euler Equations
alternative_methods.description: Instead of energy methods, write force and moment balance equations. For translation: sum of vertical spring forces equals mass times vertical acceleration. For rotation: moment of spring forces about the center equals rotational inertia times angular acceleration. Linearize for small \(\theta\) and express in matrix form to find natural frequencies.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Physically intuitive, directly shows how forces and moments act. Cons: Algebra can be slightly longer and more error-prone than energy method, especially when computing moments.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: Useful when students are more comfortable with free-body diagrams than with energy methods or when external forces are present.

alternative_methods.name: Mode Guessing and Effective Stiffness
alternative_methods.description: Assume mode shapes based on symmetry: Mode I is pure translation (\(\theta = 0\)), Mode II is pure rotation with zero net vertical force (center stays at same height). For each assumed mode, compute effective stiffness and inertia directly and then \(\omega = \sqrt{k_{eff}/m_{eff}}\).
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Very quick once you recognize the symmetry; avoids full matrix derivation. Cons: Requires correct physical intuition about mode shapes; may not generalize to asymmetric systems.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: Best for symmetric systems with obvious mode shapes, such as exam problems where speed is important.

connections_to_other_subjects.Flight Mechanics: Rigid body modes of aircraft (phugoid, short-period, Dutch roll) also involve coupled translation and rotation, similar to this bar-spring system.
connections_to_other_subjects.Control Systems: The natural frequencies derived here correspond to poles of the uncontrolled system; understanding them is essential for designing vibration control or active suspension systems.
connections_to_other_subjects.Space Dynamics: Attitude dynamics of spacecraft with flexible appendages combine rigid body rotation with structural vibration, extending the ideas from this simple rigid bar model.
connections_to_other_subjects.Solid Mechanics: The use of mass moment of inertia and rigid body kinematics is rooted in engineering mechanics and strength of materials.

deeper_dive_topics: Modal analysis of multi-degree-of-freedom systems with both rigid body and elastic modes
Semi-definite systems and treatment of zero-frequency rigid body modes
Coupling between translational and rotational modes in asymmetric spring configurations
Experimental modal testing of rigid structures mounted on isolators

syllabus_mapping.gate_subsection: Structural dynamics and aeroelasticity: Free and forced vibration of discrete systems
syllabus_mapping.feedback_for_syllabus_design: The question nicely integrates rigid body dynamics with vibration analysis, reinforcing the importance of recognizing both translational and rotational modes in structural systems.

rag_quality.notes: RAG context focused on rigid body modes, semi-definite systems, and modal analysis for bars and multi-DOF systems. While it did not provide this exact bar-on-two-springs example, it reinforced the concepts of rigid body modes, zero/low natural frequencies, and eigenvalue problems, which are conceptually related. The detailed numerical solution relied primarily on internal knowledge of rigid body vibration modeling.

future_questions_potential: Ask for the mode shapes (relative motion of ends) for the two modes of the bar-spring system.
Modify the problem with unequal spring stiffnesses and ask students to derive coupled natural frequencies.
Include damping in the springs and ask for damped natural frequencies or modal damping ratios.
Extend to a bar with an additional central spring and ask for all three natural frequencies.

response_json.subject: Aerospace Engineering
response_json.question_text: A uniform rigid prismatic bar of total mass m is suspended from a ceiling by two identical springs as shown in figure. Let omega1 and omega2 be the natural frequencies of mode I and mode II respectively (omega1 < omega2). The value of omega2/omega1 is _________ (rounded off to one decimal place).
